Betty Lou Jensen (July 22, 1952 – December 20, 1968) was a 16-year-old honor student from Benicia, California who, together with her boyfriend David Faraday, became the first known victims later attributed to the Zodiac Killer. Born in Kiowa County, Colorado, she moved to Benicia and attended Hogan High School, where she was a popular student and a talented artist. Jensen was active in the Prima Vera Council #132 Pythian Sunshine Girls and attended the Christian Science Church ([www.shadowofthezodiac.com](https://www.shadowofthezodiac.com/victims/lake-herman-rd/#:~:text=17%20Gender%3A%20Male%20,a%20native%20of%20San%20Rafael)).

Between 11:05 and 11:10 p.m. an unidentified assailant fired at their vehicle and then shot Faraday at close range. As Jensen fled, the attacker chased her and shot her multiple times; she died at the scene ([Zodiac Killer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiac_Killer#:~:text=Lake%20Herman%20Road%20murders)). The murders shocked the Bay Area and were later claimed by the Zodiac Killer in his letters. Jensen’s death marked the beginning of a still-unsolved series of killings that terrorized Northern California in the late 1960s.

CHESTER CLARK KLINGEL Jr. May 27,1926 ~ January 17, 2017 Chester Clark Klingel Jr. "Chet" was born in San Francisco CA to Alice Marjorie Stewart and Chester Clark Klingel. He grew up in Alameda CA. After honorable discharge, he worked at North American Aviation developing oscilloscopes. He farmed in the Armargosa desert, then returned to SF to work for Fireman's Fund Insurance. Chet's first wife Yolanda passed away in a car accident. His second marriage was short but his third to Blandina Sarkis added love, happiness, family and great food to his life. 
He had many good years in Tam Valley, CA, before beginning a farming venture near Turlock, CA. Chet and Blandina bought nut orchards and developed a successful walnut hulling and drying business. 
After Blandina passed away, the farming project lost appeal. Chet sold the farm and moved to Eureka, CA, where he made new friends. He spent his last decade working on winning the sweepstakes and enjoying his breakfast club friends Wesley, Joe, Chris, Pansy, and Joyce. Chet loved the ocean, bays, pigeons, building projects, his friends, driving, Yosemite, barbequing, pinching Blandina's nose, and singing.

[NY Times obituary](https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/13/business/kjell-qvale-an-instigator-of-americas-love-of-sports-cars-dies-at-94.html):
Kjell Qvale, who fell in love with a forest-green, wire-wheel MG sports car in the 1940s and went on to become one of the earliest American importers of European cars, ultimately selling a million automobiles as a distributor and dealer, died on Nov. 1 in San Francisco. He was 94.
His family announced the death.
As a recently discharged Navy veteran, the Norwegian-born Kjell Qvale (pronounced shell KAH-vah-leh) entered the car business in 1946, using $8,500 in savings to invest in a Jeep dealership in Alameda, Calif. He had no particular passion for cars at the time; to him, this was strictly a business proposition.
It was also strictly business when he made a trip to New Orleans to meet with an importer to discuss expanding his line by adding James motorcycles, a not-terribly-fast British make known for its Jeep-like practicality. There, Mr. Qvale found himself standing on a street corner when “this goofy-looking car pulls up to the curb in front of me,” he said in an interview in 2008. He asked the driver where it was made.
“England,” the driver said.
The car was the MG, and the driver turned out to be the importer of motorcycles he had come to see. He gave Mr. Qvale a ride.
It also turned out that the importer was looking for someone to market MGs in Northern California. Mr. Qvale returned to Alameda, which is just south of Oakland, Calif., sold the Jeep franchise and became an MG distributor.
The MG, the first imported sports car to appear in significant numbers on American highways, has been called “the sports car America loved first.” Its precision handling, accurate steering and zip made going to the grocery store a pleasure.
“It’s fun to drive,” Mr. Qvale told The Wall Street Journal in 1960.
In 2005, the trade publication Automotive News said the MG’s postwar popularity in the United States “was largely because of one man, Kjell Qvale.” It characterized him as “the most imaginative and probably the hardest-working” importer.
Mr. Qvale added more British cars — Aston Martin, Austin, Austin-Healey, Jaguar, Morris, Bentley and Rolls-Royce — and became the exclusive distributor of these brands in Northern California and other parts of the West. (His dealership sold more Austin-Healey 3000s than any other American.) He later added the German cars Volkswagen and Porsche and, later still, Japanese makes.
At his peak, around 1970, he operated 100 dealerships. He estimated that as a wholesale distributor and retail dealer, he sold a million cars representing 36 makes.
Mr. Qvale’s impact in popularizing sportier, more luxurious European cars in the West is often compared to that of Max Hoffman, the celebrated New York car importer who commissioned Frank Lloyd Wright to design his Manhattan showroom.
Mr. Qvale, like Mr. Hoffman, overcame stiff obstacles. He persuaded reluctant banks to finance his unfamiliar breeds of car and insurance companies to insure them. He also had the logistically demanding task of providing parts and service for the foreign brands.
He promoted sports cars by sponsoring rallies, time trials and other competitions. In 1949, he organized the first postwar sports car race in the West at Buchanan Field in Concord, Calif. The next year, he was chairman of the first sports car race in the forest at Pebble Beach, Calif. To accompany the race, he proposed a show of classic cars; it became the [Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance](http://www.pebblebeachconcours.net/), one of the top events in the world for car collectors.
In 1956, when the Pebble Beach race moved to nearby Fort Ord, an Army base, Mr. Qvale contributed to the design of its famously treacherous corkscrew at turns 8 and 8A of what is now [Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca](http://www.mazdaraceway.com/corkscrew-passport). He also organized a sports car race on the public roads of Golden Gate Park in San Francisco and teamed up with the racecar designer Joe Huffaker to race MGs at Indianapolis in the mid-1960s.
Kjell Qvale was born on July 17, 1919, in Trondheim, Norway, about 225 miles north of Oslo. His father, Bjarne, was a sea captain who commanded a freighter that operated between Chile and Seattle. The elder Mr. Qvale decided to leave the merchant marine and settle in the Pacific Northwest because it reminded him of Norway. Kjell was 10 when his mother took him and his four siblings to join their father.
As a boy, Kjell sold vegetable graters and phonograph needles door to door and had a newspaper delivery route. He was a track star in high school and won an athletic scholarship to the University of Washington, where he was captain of the track team. He once ran the 100-yard dash in 9.6 seconds in a collegiate meet.
He joined the Navy after Pearl Harbor and flew transport planes in the Pacific during World War II. A wartime friend who was the San Francisco-area distributor for Willys-Overland Motors, which made Jeeps, helped him get the Alameda franchise.
In 1970, Mr. Qvale teamed up with the car designer Donald Healey to buy Jensen Motors, and together they developed the Jensen-Healey, a powerful sports car with a Lotus 907 engine. They sold the car from 1972 to 1976. As majority shareholder in Jensen Motors, Mr. Qvale also sought to acquire Rolls-Royce but was unsuccessful.
In 1998, Mr. Qvale and his sons, Jeff and Bruce, bought the rights to make the DeTomaso Mangusta, a high-performance sports car. They made and sold several hundred before selling the rights and manufacturing plant to the MG Rover group in 2001.
Mr. Qvale’s other business interests included Brittania Jeans and the First National Bank of Marin. He bred and raced thoroughbreds and for a time owned the renowned come-from-behind racehorse Silky Sullivan. He also financed women’s professional tennis.
Mr. Qvale’s wife of 57 years (and his business associate for even longer), the former Kay Curry, died in 2005. He is survived by his sons, seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild.
Always eager to try something new, Mr. Qvale started taking piano lessons at 90.

**_San Francisco Express Times_** was a [counterculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counterculture) tabloid [underground newspaper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underground_press) edited by Marvin Garson and published weekly in [San Francisco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco), [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California) from January 24, 1968, to March 25, 1969, for a total of 61 issues, covering and promoting [radical politics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radical_politics), [rock music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rock_music), arts and [progressive culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_culture) in the [Bay Area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Area).[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-loc-1) It was a member of the [Underground Press Syndicate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underground_Press_Syndicate), and sold for 15 cents.
Starting in April 1969 the _San Francisco Express Times_ changed its name to **_Good Times_**, publishing under that title with a substantially different editorial policy, lasting until August 2, 1972.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-loc2-2) In 2021, _[Newsweek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newsweek)_ referred to _Good Times_ as an "anti-police and pro-violence" publication.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-Newsweek-3)

**Publication history**

**_Express Times_**
Marvin Garson was a graduate of the University of California and a veteran of the Berkeley [Free Speech Movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Speech_Movement), where he edited an FSM newsletter, _Wooden Shoe_, along with his wife [Barbara Garson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barbara_Garson). He started the _Express Times_ with co-founder [Bob Novick](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bob_Novick&action=edit&redlink=1).[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-4) Some members of the _[San Francisco Oracle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Oracle)_ collective were also involved in the paper's birth.
The _Express Times_ featured a weekly cooking column, _30 Recipes Suitable for Framing_, written by [Alice Waters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_Waters) and illustrated by [David Lance Goines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Lance_Goines).[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-sighswhispers/11-goines-5) Regular contributors included [Todd Gitlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Todd_Gitlin), [Greil Marcus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greil_Marcus), [Paul Williams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Williams_(Crawdaddy!_creator)), Sandy Darlington, and [Marjorie Heins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marjorie_Heins).[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-6) Catherine Yronwode, later known for her work in the comics industry, co-wrote a weekly astrology column for the _Express Times_. Staff photographers were Jeffrey Blankfort, followed by Nacio Jan Brown and [Robert Altman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Altman_(photographer)). Cartoons and illustrations were provided by [Jaxon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaxon_(cartoonist)), the syndicated editorial cartoons of [Ron Cobb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ron_Cobb), and [Sharon Rudahl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharon_Rudahl).[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-7)
During the year of its existence, highlights included extensive on-the-scene coverage of student rioting and the prolonged strike at [San Francisco State University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_State_University), and Lenny Heller's serialized novel of guerrilla warfare in the United States, _Berkeley Guns_.
In December 1968 editor Marvin Garson spent 20 days in jail in Chicago as a result of his participation as a journalist in a police and protester skirmish during the [Democratic National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1968_Democratic_National_Convention) in August.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-8)
Documents released under the [Freedom of Information Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_Information_Act_(United_States)) show that the _Express Times_ was one of a number of underground newspapers successfully infiltrated by the [FBI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation), which had a paid informant on the staff.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-9)

**_Good Times_**
The renamed _Good Times_ paper debuted in April 1969; the all-volunteer editorial collective was made up of residents of the Good Times [Commune](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intentional_community).[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-MysteryQuest-10) Under this regime, the paper's contents and publication schedule were a good deal more relaxed than when it was the _San Francisco Express Times_.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_]
[Jesse Drew](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jesse_Drew) of the San Francisco digital archive _Found SF_ described _Good Times_ this way:
> _Good Times_ was the paper the [radical left](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Far-left_politics) depended upon to keep up with the [anti-war movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-war_movement), the trials of political prisoners like the [Soledad Brothers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soledad_Brothers) and [Angela Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angela_Davis), political corruption in San Francisco, and general communal information like vegetarian recipes and holistic health care. The all-volunteer collective put out _Good Times_ on a regular bi-weekly, weekly, and then twice-a-week basis until sputtering out in the summer of 1972.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-11)
Underground cartoonist [Harry Driggs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Driggs) served as _Good Times_'s art director and staff cartoonist; he recruited fellow underground cartoonists [Trina Robbins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trina_Robbins)[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-12) and [Guy Colwell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guy_Colwell)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-Colwell-13) as contributors (Collwell, in fact, joined the Good Times Commune).[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-Colwell-13) Writer [Nina Serrano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nina_Serrano) wrote a series of articles on the [Los Siete trial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Siete_de_la_Raza) and contributed poetry to _Good Times_.
When _Good Times_ decided to accept [pornographic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pornographic) display advertising and classified [sex trade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_trade) advertising in early 1970, [feminist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feminist) staff members staged an action to prevent this from happening.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_] When male staffers at _Good Times_ tried to put out a special "Sex" issue, women staffers stole the mock-ups and page layouts and burned them.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_]

**Legacy**
In 1977, [Allan Francovich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allan_Francovich) and Gene Rosow produced and directed a documentary on the newspaper titled _San Francisco Good Times_, which included appearances by such notable figures as [Pete Townsend](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Townshend) of [The Who](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Who) and [Timothy Leary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timothy_Leary).[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-14)

The [History Channel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_(U.S._TV_channel))'s 2009 television program _[MysteryQuest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MysteryQuest)_ speculated that a member of the Good Times Commune, Richard Gaikowski (1936–2004), was a possible suspect in the unsolved San Francisco [Zodiac Killer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiac_Killer) case.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-MysteryQuest-10) His appearance resembled a composite sketch of the killer, and a police dispatcher who had been contacted by the Zodiac, identified a recording of Gaikowski's voice as being the same as the Zodiac's.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-15)
In 2021, _[Newsweek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newsweek)_ published an article that also mentioned Gaikowski in relation to the Zodiac killings.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Express_Times#cite_note-Newsweek-3)

Biography:
Born at home in Napa in 1905, Pete Gasser was one of six children of Swiss immigrants Henry Gasser and Mary Crotta, who had come to the United States in the 1880’s and 90’s. Like most of their neighbors, the Gassers were farmers, and for many years his father was the head dairyman at Napa State Hospital. At their ranch in Coombsville, the family had their own prune orchard, raised turkeys and chickens, and operated a dairy with goats and cows. The Gasser dairy was known for neatness and modern methods of operation, and working in it throughout his childhood taught the young Peter plenty about hard work. In high school, he was annoyed when other boys teased him about his rustic clothes, and left after ninth grade, but he soon went on to earn a banking certificate in San Francisco. He began working for the Bank of Italy (which was to become the Bank of America) in 1925.
Pete’s new job brought him into contact with bankers, local business owners, and other men of influence and power. It also allowed him to dress the part of the promising young businessman, and he impressed the young widow Vernice Wilson, whom he began escorting around Napa. The two were married in 1934. Pete Gasser soon left banking, telling friends that the Bank of America “wouldn’t let him run it the way he wanted to,” and went into business selling used cars in Napa, perhaps with his father’s help. After a rocky beginning he opened his own Dodge agency, promoted with a splashy opening that featured live vaudeville, free movies and branded souvenirs. The agency also sponsored a winning basketball team, who were provided with fine uniforms and chauffeured to the games in shiny late model Dodge cars. Pete Gasser was a natural business promoter, and became known around Napa as the man to talk to for a good deal on an automobile. But Napa suffered big losses during the Depression, and Mr. Gasser felt that the town needed direction from the Chamber of Commerce, which had lost drive and membership, in order to recover and prosper.
As his own business gradually gathered momentum, Pete Gasser gave the Chamber of Commerce new vitality and purpose. Starting as a member-at-large in 1938, he soon moved up to president from 1941-45, and remained influential for a long time afterward. With the national economy beginning to recover, and the possibility of another war in Europe on the horizon, Mr. Gasser insisted that the group take an active part in improving the city – pressuring for annexation of surrounding areas to accommodate new workers, arranging construction of infrastructure, and asking members to build housing for the booming population. The Chamber’s powerful voice was effective in directing Napa development before and during World War II. Under their auspices, Gasser facilitated the widening of Highway 29 between Napa and Vallejo and helped envisage the Napa airport. He was influential in negotiating with the federal government to construct wartime housing, and lobbied for dredging the channel from Carquinez Straits to Napa. At the same time he expanded his own business dealings into heavy trucks and other vehicles. He invested in other local businesses, notably Basalt Rock Company, bought more real estate, and brokered deals for the city.
Though he never ran for elected office, Gasser himself was a major force for change in Napa, with business and civic projects that became almost too numerous to track between 1940 and 1975. His opinions influenced the mayor, supervisors and newspaper, and his influence, or lack of it, could make a project succeed or fail. As president of the Chamber, he was War Fund chairman for the American Red Cross, and was cited for distinguished achievement in raising funds for the group to support troops overseas. He helped bring the Oakland Oaks baseball team to Napa for spring training.
Gasser served on the advisory boards of the Bank of America, Silverado Council of the Boy Scouts, Napa Farm Bureau, and Native Sons of the Golden West, and promoted their interests through the Chamber of Commerce. He presided over the establishment of Robert Louis Stevenson State Park. Following his predecessor Nathan Coombs, Mr. Gasser served on the Golden Gate Bridge Authority, and represented Napa interests to the mayor and supervisors of San Francisco for twenty years. He became director of the Redwood Empire Association, and acted as co-chairman of fundraising efforts to build Queen of the Valley Hospital. He was a generous benefactor of Justin-Siena School. In later years, he helped expedite construction of the Southern Crossing via the Butler bridge south of Napa, a major transit project. In 1965, he sold Gasser Motors to devote himself to real estate and Napa Valley development. The Napa Register’s story quoted him saying that the development of the Napa Valley was “in its infancy,” and that “tremendous growth would be coming to the area in the very near future, after such needs as sanitation, adequate water for industry and domestic use and recreational needs were solved.” With increasing financial resources at hand, Pete Gasser purchased land for many more projects, including the remainder of the 145 acre site of today’s South Napa Marketplace. He envisioned the area along Soscol Avenue between Napa State Hospital and downtown as a major shopping area for the city, and began looking for businesses to make his dream a reality.
Throughout the years, Pete Gasser approached relaxation as he did business–with gusto, in the company of many colleagues and friends. He was known for his “big” personality, and success allowed him to enjoy himself in the rollicking style of his era. An enthusiastic hunter and fisherman who loved the outdoors, he had special fences constructed on his property to accommodate the native deer, and was a major supporter of Ducks Unlimited. He had his pond stocked with rainbow trout, hunted deer in Nevada, and took a state senator salmon fishing in Alaska; he even hunted a polar bear. He also greatly enjoyed golf and was a charter member and the first president of the Silverado Country Club. While keeping his finger on the pulse of Napa, he became the larger than life figure that he clearly wanted to be.
There were the ranch hands he bailed out of jail; the employee with bad credit whom he still backed. Success did not rob him of the pleasure of doing favors for his friends. Yet more than anything else he was an astute businessman who relished envisioning projects and bringing them to fruition. He enjoyed knowing the right people to get things done, and working with them to accomplish the job. In his later days Gasser told a friend that he “hoped to leave something to the world so that I’ll be remembered.” The Gassers had no children, and as Pete had made his money in Napa, he wanted his inheritance to benefit the Napa community. He directed that his legacy be planned in the same way he had lived: carefully, strategically, and with Napa interests at heart. The Gasser Foundation continues the work that Pete would have done himself by contributing to all levels of the Napa community, because–to the end–Pete Gasser believed in Napa, and insisted that this commitment also be put “in black and white.”
The Gasser Foundation, surely, is something wonderfully generous for all Napa citizens to remember him by. Napa native Vernice Gasser was a daughter of the prominent Stoddard family, who arrived in California by wagon train from Michigan in 1871. Her grandfather, William Stoddard, settled in Napa in 1880, and with his sons soon established a prosperous grain and feed business which became one of the largest in the region, milling barley and corn. Vernice’s father, William Stoddard, Jr., died when she was only eleven, leaving her French-born mother Isabelle Ilos Stoddard to carry on the milling business. Though placed in an unusual position for a woman of her time, Mrs. Stoddard proved to be an outstanding manager of business affairs. She became a mortgage lender, began to acquire real estate, and advised other businesses on matters of finance; she worked at Napa’s department store (Albert’s), taught knitting there and in her home, and did volunteer work at the hospital.
In many ways Vernice, who preferred to be called Pat, was to follow her mother in her civic and business interests. Women of her era were beginning to assume greater responsibilities outside the home, and participating, though often behind the scenes, in business decisions. She attended business school in Oakland, where she received a certificate in bookkeeping and typing, and took her first job at Mare Island Naval Yard in 1920. She married John Wilson of Suisun, but after his sudden death in 1930 she returned to Napa and worked as office manager at Albert’s department store. Four years later, she married the up-and-coming young businessman Pete Gasser, and in 1937, the two opened Gasser Motors Dodge Cars & Trucks’ new showroom with a staff of thirty-one. Mrs. Gasser was in charge of bookkeeping and managed the office.
She had done volunteer work during World War I, and when World War II came she again became involved with the Red Cross and other charities. One of them began as “Bundles for Britain”, a war relief organization supporting British servicemen early in World War II; it later supported U.S. servicemen. Pat and other volunteers opened a salvage shop that proved to be such a fundraising success that the group continued to operate after the war on behalf of the Napa community. Pat Gasser was a founding member of the group, now known as Community Projects, and it became her major focus. Over the years she served in the capacities of CP president, treasurer, thrift shop chairman and hospital auxiliary chair, and under her direction an invitation to join CP became a coveted honor. She also spearheaded the purchase of CP’s current location as an investment for the organization. The organization made her a life member in 1986. Outside of Community Projects, Pat Gasser helped raise funds and served as trustee for the Queen of the Valley Hospital Foundation, and was named Woman of the Year by the Napa Business and Professional Women’s Club in recognition of her work for the town.
Pat was an enthusiastic gardener, regularly winning ribbons for her flowers at the Napa Town & Country Fair. She retained a childhood love of horses, and in 1939 helped to organize the Napa Valley Horsemen’s Association. Known around town as a stylish dresser with a taste for beautiful things, she was also an adventurous world traveler, venturing abroad to Asia, South America, and several regions of Africa. Though at heart the dynamic Mrs. Gasser and her husband Pete were intensely private individuals, both felt a lifelong affection for Napa. Mrs. Gasser agreed that establishing the Gasser Foundation as a charitable entity would be the finest and most enduring legacy they could leave their community. When she died in 1989, seven years after her husband, Mrs. Gasser had made sure that these dreams would become a reality. As in life, her closest and most abiding connection was with her hometown.

## **William Langley Beeman**
## **OBITUARY**
Jan. 7, 1921 – Feb. 1, 2009 Attorney William Langley Beeman died on February 1 at Kaiser Hospital in Vallejo. He was 88 years old.
Bill was born on January 7, 1921, in Fort Worth, Texas. He was the 10th of 10 children of Edwin A. and Lucille E. (Shoemake) Beeman. In his early childhood, the family lived on a farm outside of Golden, Oklahoma. Bill moved to Vallejo the first time with his mother, brother Jack and sister Ruth in October of 1928, residing in Hudson Alley. While attending Lincoln Elementary School and Vallejo Junior High School, he helped to support his family by selling newspapers for five years, seven days a week.
In 1933, Bill moved with his mother and brother Jack to Old Town, in San Diego, where he again sold newspapers for most of his high school years. He graduated from Point Loma High School in 1939 and then attended San Diego State College.
While attending college, he worked as a night watchman for the Bill Gibbs Flying School, being paid with flying lessons. Discovering an enormous love of flying, he quickly obtained his commercial and flight instructors’ licenses. Prior to World War II, he taught flying for the Civilian Pilot Training Program in the Imperial Valley. In June of 1941 he became a flight instructor at Falcon Field in Mesa, Arizona, teaching Royal Air Force cadets skills in primary, basic and advanced flying.
In June of 1942, Bill went to work as a co-pilot for Consairway in San Diego, delivering PBYs and B-24s for the war effort. In 1943, he then became a flight captain for Consairway. Flying under contract for the Army and Navy Transport Commands, Bill’s responsibilities took him through the entire South Pacific, including Australia, New Guinea, Fiji Islands, Biak, Funafuti, and Tarawa. Between flights across the South Pacific, he was a test pilot and delivered planes to the East Coast.
In August of 1945, Bill Beeman married Nancy Jane Chandler from Vacaville, and within a few months he was drafted. He served in Korea with the Army Air Office in Seoul, and was honorably discharged in 1947.
Continuing his flying career, he then worked as an instructor with the Vacaville Dixon Flying Service until he moved to Pacific Overseas Airways in Los Angeles and then Peruvian International Airlines in Lima, Peru. When his flying career ended, Bill had completed over 6,000 hours of flying time.
After he was seriously burned in a fuel explosion and experienced significant legal problems as a result, Bill decided to enter the legal profession. In 1949, he started night school at the McGeorge College of Law in Sacramento. During this time, he worked as a bridge tender and telegraph switch operator for the Southern Pacific Railroad. In the last 15 months of law school, he worked as a U.S. Deputy Clerk for the Federal Court. He graduated with distinction from law school as second in his class, and started his own practice in Vallejo in January of 1954.
During his 50 plus years in the practice of law, Attorney Beeman pursued each of his cases with a fiercely competitive spirit, applying his keen intellect, his gift of storytelling, and his loyalty to the rule of law. In short, he hated to lose. In his trial work, no one ever accused Bill Beeman of a lack of effort. Throughout his law practice, he was genuinely interested in his clients, treating each with respect and sincere friendship.
Bill was devoted to Vallejo and Solano County. He led the efforts to establish the Solano County Legal Aid and Mental Health Programs. He was a lifetime member of the NAACP and served as president of the Solano County Bar Association. He enriched many childrens’ lives as a swimming instructor for the YMCA. Bill was also an energetic supporter of the Democratic Party, being involved in the local Democratic Club and in many local campaigns of state and national candidates.
In 1969, he married Eileen Posedel of Vallejo. He enjoyed golf, fishing, and waterskiing. Throughout his whole life, Bill was busy with his law practice, or community work, or political involvement, or writing, or family É all at the same time.
Bill Beeman is survived by his children, Paul L. Beeman (Donna Kenney), Rockne C. Beeman, Kimberly S. Vaughn (Bill), William L. Beeman II, and Frederick P. Beeman; his grandchildren, Lauren, William, Andrew, Ryan and Sarah; and great-grandchild, Kylie.
Services will be held on Saturday, February 21, at 11 a.m. at First United Methodist Church, 502 Virginia Street, Vallejo.
In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Lung Association.

**Pacific Union College** (**PUC**) is a [private](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_university) [Seventh-day Adventist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church) [liberal arts college](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_arts_colleges_in_the_United_States) in [Angwin, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angwin,_California). It is the only four-year college in [Napa County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napa_County,_California), and the twelfth oldest institution of higher education in California.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:4-5) As a [coeducational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coeducation) residential college with an almost exclusively undergraduate student body, most of those who attend the college are four-year students living on campus.
PUC is accredited by the [WASC Senior College and University Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WASC_Senior_College_and_University_Commission) and maintains various programmatic accreditation for specific programs. Enrollment at Pacific Union College is roughly 825.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:6-6) The college offers about 60 [undergraduate majors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undergraduate_degree) and three [master's programs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master%27s_degree) organized in 25 academic departments, with its [health science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_science) degrees the largest number of those sought out by students.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:3-7)[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:6-6) The campus occupies 200 acres (0.81 km2) of the college's 1,800 acres (7.3 km2) in property.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:3-7)

[Sidney Brownsberger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sidney_Brownsberger) served as its first President. Under his term, the academy focused on both conventional study of standard subjects as well as practical skills, such as [dressmaking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dressmaker), [blacksmithing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blacksmith), [carpentry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carpentry), and [cooking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooking), in line with White's desire for the college.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:4-5)[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:8-9)[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-10) The lengthy tenure of William C. Grainger saw the heyday of the Academy's early years, but with the turn of the century, poor financial management led to increasing debt that eventually forced the academy to close in July 1908.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:4-5)[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-11)
**Move to Angwin (1909–1921)**
An early image of Pacific Union College's new campus in Angwin
Despite this failure, many church leaders – including White herself – continued to push for expanded Adventist schooling, and efforts were begun in the 1900s to find a new location to rebuild the college. Many sites were scouted out in the [Central Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Valley_(California)) and elsewhere within the state, but none came to the satisfaction of the searchers.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:4-5)
Eventually, in 1909, the [Pacific Union Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_American_Division_of_Seventh-day_Adventists) announced that it had found an opening to purchase the 1,636 acres of the [Angwin Resort](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angwin,_California) on [Howell Mountain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howell_Mountain,_California) in neighboring [Napa County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napa_County). The property had been found through the church's St. Helena Sanitarium, and White visited the site in September in 1909.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-12)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:9-13) Satisfied with the condition of its facilities and living quarters and the ease with which they could be adapted for teaching purposes, its abundant resources in [springs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spring_(hydrology)) and [lumber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lumber), and the healthful living its geography would provide, White approved the location.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:8-9)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:9-13) The property was bought in the same month for $60,000 (roughly $1.9 million in 2022), and opened its doors September 29.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:8-9)[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-14) The name of the college was finalized as **Pacific Union College** in 1910 to reflect change in location, even as it had changed names a few times before.
PUC's first president at Angwin was Charles W. Irwin, who served from the opening of the new location until 1921. Irwin's term was marked by [self-sufficiency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-sustainability) as the college adapted to its new location, with both the faculty and student body working to expand the campus through the area's available [natural resources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resource).[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:4-5)
**Early 20th century (1922–1943)**
In the 1920s and 1930s, PUC expanded its educational programs with the goal of receiving [educational accreditation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Educational_accreditation). Driven by suggestions from the college's [board](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Board_of_directors), PUC required that professors have [postgraduate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postgraduate_education) degrees to teach, created lower and [upper divisions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_division_college), introduced [major](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academic_major) and [minor degrees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academic_minor), and necessitated the completion of [senior theses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thesis) for graduation. The college also extended funds to pay for faculty members' graduate studies.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:4-5) With these changes, PUC became the first Adventist college to become accredited when it was awarded accreditation by the [Northwest Association of Secondary and Higher Schools](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northwest_Association_of_Secondary_and_Higher_Schools) in 1933.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-jaetimeline-15)
This era also saw further expansion of the campus community through the construction of more facilities – including new men's [dormitories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dormitory) and its current [gymnasium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gym) – as well as through the creation of the college's first [student association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Students%27_union), the Associated Students of Pacific Union College (ASPUC), in January 1935. The college's student newspaper, the _Campus Chronicle_, published its first issue in 1925 after being adapted from the previous _Mountain Echo_, while the _Diogenes Lantern_, PUC's current [yearbook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yearbook), was first published in 1938.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:4-5)
With the United States' entry into [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II), over 400 male students and [alumni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alumni) were eventually [drafted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conscription) into military service.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:4-5)
**Other history (1943–2023)**
In 2006 the faculty, administration, and Board of Trustees underscored PUC's commitment to undergraduate education by making a formal decision to remain a college and not change its name to university, as other small private colleges had done.[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-reaccred-16)
In 2006, PUC's Board of Trustees made plans to transform the area into an [ecovillage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecovillage) of several hundred settlements, in partnership with Triad Development, a [Seattle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle)-based construction firm.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-17) Although the college downscaled its original plans due to community opposition – primarily by **Save Rural Angwin**, a local [NIMBY](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NIMBY) group – the board voted in October 2010 to sever its contract with Triad and cancel the project.[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-18)[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:1-19)[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-chronicle-20)
Pacific Union College has had a total of [twenty-four presidents](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_Pacific_Union_College). The first eight of these served while the school was still in Healdsburg. In 1983, Malcolm Maxwell became the first alumnus to lead PUC, serving for a record 18 years. Ralph Trecartin, the current president, took office in July 2021 after serving as the associate provost and dean of the College of Professionals for [Andrews University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrews_University).[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-21)

Academics
Pacific Union College is the only four-year college located in [Napa County, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napa_County,_California).[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-22) It offers around 60 undergraduate majors in various fields, along with other types of programs. [Health science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_science), [business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business), and [education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Education) are the leading fields in which students seek out degrees, and their degree programs are [accredited](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Programmatic_Accreditation) by their [respective accreditation bodies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#accreditation).[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:6-6)
**Curriculum**
Pacific Union College offers 44 [bachelor's degree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree) programs, 10 [associate degree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associate_degree) programs, and three [master's degree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master%27s_degree) programs, in addition to minors, credential programs, pre-professional tracks, and an honors program.[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:0-23) These are all organized throughout 25 academic departments.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:3-7) The school operates on a quarter-based academic calendar.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:13-24)
Though the range of its offerings is quite broad, PUC's most prominent programs are those in the [health sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_health_sciences), which are sought out by a considerable number of those who attend. In the 2020–2021 school year, two-thirds of all undergraduate degrees awarded were in the medical field, and 96% of the associate's degrees awarded were for nursing.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:6-6)
PUC maintains an especially close connection to [Loma Linda University School of Medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loma_Linda_University_School_of_Medicine), another Adventist institution, and most of the college's pre-professional programs are meant specifically for admission into Loma Linda.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:3-7) The college has sent a steady stream of students to the university for several decades; visiting from Loma Linda in 1925, [John H. Kellogg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Harvey_Kellogg) noted that PUC was "the college that sends the largest number of medical students from any one place."[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-25) Degrees in business and education follow behind as the second two most sought-after.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:6-6)
Similar to its emphasis on [manual labor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manual_labour) and [physical health](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_health) in its Healdsburg days, PUC necessitates that students takes fitness classes as part of its general education requirements.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:3-7) Offerings in the past have included [fencing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fencing), [trikke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trikke), [pickleball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pickleball), [swimming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swimming_(sport)), [water aerobics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_aerobics), [polo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polo), [canoeing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canoeing), [skiing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skiing), [snowboarding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowboarding), [soccer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soccer), [dance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dance), and [yoga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoga), though some of these have since been discontinued.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-26)
Similar to other Adventist schools, PUC offers study-abroad programs through **Adventist Colleges Abroad** (**ACA**), primarily in Europe and Latin America.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-27)[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-28) Most of these programs were designed for those seeking degrees from the college's World Languages Department, though non-language majors often study abroad through the ACA as well.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-29)[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-30) PUC also organizes [mission trips](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short-term_mission) independently of ACA.[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-31)[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-32)[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-33)
**Rankings**
At the start of the 2023–2024, the _[U.S. News & World Report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._News_%26_World_Report)_ ranked Pacific Union College the 13th best regional college in the [Western United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_United_States), the 12th top performer in [social mobility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_mobility) (a position in shares with the [Fashion Institute of Design & Merchandising](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fashion_Institute_of_Design_%26_Merchandising)), and the second Best Value School.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:13-24) In the same year, the _[New York Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times)_ ranked PUC the 8th most economically diverse college in the U.S. [Niche](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niche_(company)) gives the college an overall B− score, and ranks it the 24th most diverse college in California, with its diversity graded A+. It also ranks PUC as the 14th best nursing college in California.[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-34)
In 2024, _[Washington Monthly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Monthly)_ ranked Pacific Union College 35th among 223 colleges that award almost exclusively bachelor's degrees in the U.S. based on its contribution to the public good, as measured by social mobility, research, and promoting public service. [[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-35)
**Accreditation**
Pacific Union College has been [accredited](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higher_education_accreditation_in_the_United_States) by the [WASC Senior College and University Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WASC_Senior_College_and_University_Commission) or its predecessor since 1951.[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-36) In February 2020, however, the commission issued a formal Notice of Concern regarding the college's accreditation, citing PUC's dwindling financial resources and dramatic drops in enrollment as areas that needed improvement.[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-37) Though in the years following PUC noted moderate increases in enrollment and dismissed a number of its employees in response to WSCUC's recommendations, the commission has not withdrawn its Notice of Concern.[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-38)[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-39)[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-40) PUC is also accredited by the Adventist Church's own [Adventist Accrediting Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adventist_Accrediting_Association).[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-41)[[a]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-42)
In addition to these two institution-wide accreditations, many of PUC's programs and departments are accredited or approved by their respective programmatic accreditation bodies, including:
- [National Association of Schools of Art and Design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Association_of_Schools_of_Art_and_Design)[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-43)
- [National Association of Schools of Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Association_of_Schools_of_Music)[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-44)
- California Commission on Teacher Credentialing[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:11-45)[[b]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-46)
- [International Assembly for Collegiate Business Education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Accreditation_Council_for_Business_Education)[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:10-47)
- [Council on Social Work Education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Council_on_Social_Work_Education)[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-48)

Campus and facilities
The college is located in [Angwin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angwin,_California), on [Howell Mountain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howell_Mountain,_California) overlooking the [Napa Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napa_Valley), 70 miles (110 km) north of [San Francisco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco) and 60 miles (85 km) from the Pacific Ocean. The main campus comprises about only 200 acres (0.81 km2) of the college's 1,800 acres (7.3 km2) in property.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:3-7) The remaining 1,600 acres (6.5 km2) is managed as a [conservation easement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_easement).[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:2-50)
Since 2007, [Bon Appétite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bon_App%C3%A9tit_Management_Company) has catered the **PUC Dining Commons**. It serves exclusively vegetarian and vegan menu items sourced from local producers, in accordance with [Adventist health beliefs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church#Health_and_diet) and the company's own catering methods.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:3-7)[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-51) During winter 2011, the Commons saw heavy renovations which redesigned the cafeteria's architectural style and expanded its space.[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-52) In 2021, [supply chain shortages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021%E2%80%932023_global_supply_chain_crisis) caused by [COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic) disrupted the kitchen's ability to source local ingredients.[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-53)
The college's main library is the **Nelson Memorial Library**, with holdings of around 150,000 books.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:3-7) It also houses the **Pitcairn Islands Study Center**, with a collection of materials about the [Pitcairn Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pitcairn_Islands), as well as literary collections for various figures in [Adventist history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Seventh-day_Adventist_Church). In 2011, the library was renovated at a cost of over a million dollars.[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-54)

**Angwin–Parrett Field**

Pacific Union College owns and operates Angwin–Parrett Field, a public use airport located on its campus.[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-FAA-59) The airport was the landing spot during [George W. Bush](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_W._Bush)'s presidential visit to the Napa Valley in 2006.[[58]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-60) The airport also supports PUC's Bachelor of Science degree in aviation and offers ground schools and flight instruction to the community.[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-61)
**PUC Forest**
Much of the school's undeveloped acreage is managed as the **PUC** **Demonstration & Experimental Forest**, though on campus it has sometimes been called the **Back 40**.[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:2-50) The forest was part of the [Angwin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angwin,_California) property and a site of lumber before it was bought by the college. It spans roughly 1,600 acres (6.5 km2). In addition to providing the resources necessary for the expansion of the campus in its early years, the forest has also served as a site for biological research and preservation, enclosing as it does unique [species](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Species) and [biodiversity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity).[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:2-50)[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:12-62)
In 2018, PUC partnered with the [Napa County Land Trust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napa_County,_California#Agricultural_preservation) to preserve the forest as a [conservation easement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_easement); the easement is currently held by [CalFire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Department_of_Forestry_and_Fire_Protection).[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:2-50)[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:12-62) Covering 864 acres (3.50 km2), the easement protects about half of college's total property. It was valued at $7.1 million, much of it due to [vineyard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vineyard) potential.[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:12-62) Attempts in the past have been made to develop or sell the land, however; most notably, the college made plans to transform the area into an [ecovillage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecovillage) in 2006, but it ultimately chose to cancel the project.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:1-19)
Still, with a network of hiking trails spanning 35 miles, the forest sees regular use. In 2019, the college partnered with Napa County's Open Space District to open its trail network to the public.[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-63)[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-64) The forest is also a section along the [Bay Area Ridge Trail](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bay_Area_Ridge_Trail), and was linked in the same year.[[63]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-65)[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-66) The [2009 Tour of California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Tour_of_California), an cycling race held within the state, raced through PUC.[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-67)

**Pacific Union College Church**
_Main article: [Pacific Union College Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College_Church)_
Pacific Union College Church is the campus church, built in 1968.[[66]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-PUCCAbout-68) It has around 1,600 members.[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-69) The church's large [pipe organ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College_Church#Rieger_Pipe_Organ) was built by Austrian organ-maker [Rieger Orgelbau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rieger_Orgelbau) and installed in 1981.[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-PUCCrieger-70)[[69]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-71) The church complex also has classrooms for theology classes and houses PUC's Office of Service, Justice, and Missions.
Student life
Pacific Union College's stated focus is on undergraduate education.[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-reaccred-16) In the fall of 2021, 829 students were enrolled at PUC, 825 of whom were undergraduate students.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:6-6) The school maintains a student/teacher ratio of roughly 12:1.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-pucabout-8) As a residential college, the vast majority of these students live in one of seven on-campus residence halls.
**Demographics**
Within PUC's student body, the three largest ethnic demographics are [Hispanic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hispanic) (31% in fall 2021), [Asian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asian_people) (23%), and [White](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_people) (21%), while the remaining quarter includes [Black](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_Americans) students and others. Female students make up a majority of those on campus (63%), while male students comprise about a third (37%). A large majority of students are from California (78%), with only a fraction enrolling from out of state.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:6-6) PUC was ranked as the most diverse liberal arts college in the [Western United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_United_States) by the _[U.S. News & World Report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._News_%26_World_Report)_ for the 2022–2023 school year.[[70]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-72)
PUC also maintains a [DEI Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diversity,_equity,_and_inclusion) as well as a [Title IX Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Title_IX).[[71]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-73) It accepts the WSCUC criteria for diversity: [race](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_(classification_of_humans)), [ethnicity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnicity), [socioeconomic class](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socioeconomic_class), [gender](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender), [age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ageing), [religious belief](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_belief), [sexual orientation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_orientation) and [disability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disability).[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-diversity-74)
**Student association**
The **Pacific Union College [Student Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Students%27_union)** (**PUCSA**) was started in 1887, just five years after the college was founded.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_] It consists of an executive branch and a Student Senate. PUCSA funds publication of the school's student-run newspaper, the _Campus Chronicle,_ and the college yearbook, the _Diogenes Lantern_.
**Student organizations**
There are more than 50 clubs, Honor's Associations and Student Ministries active on campus at Pacific Union College. These include the [Secular Student Alliance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secular_Student_Alliance), Biology Club, Asian Student Association, Pre-Med Club, Korean Adventist Student Association, Dramatic Arts Society, Musical Arts Symposium, Homeless Ministry, [Psi Chi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psi_Chi), [College Democrats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_Democrats) and others. In addition to the _Campus Chronicle_, there are several other student-run publications including a literary periodical, _Quicksilver_.

The logo of Gay and Straight People (GASP) in the early 2020s.**Gay and Straight People**
A [gay-straight alliance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gay-straight_alliance), **Gay and Straight People** (**GASP**), has operated on campus since October 2008. It was first organized by a pre-med student named Jonathan Heldt, who established the alliance when he was a senior in the hopes of creating a [support group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Support_group) for [LGBTQ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT) students and their [allies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Straight_ally).[[73]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:7-75) Originally intending to form an official club, Heldt's proposal was rejected by PUC's Advisory Council.[[74]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-spectrummagazine.org-76)
Students and faculty continue to meet regularly to discuss LGBTQ issues.[[74]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-spectrummagazine.org-76)[[75]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-77) Though the club remains formally unrecognized by the college, the group contributed to the expansion of [all-gender bathrooms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unisex_public_toilet) on campus, and has had presence at the college's student orientation and club fairs.[[76]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:5-78)[[73]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:7-75) In December 2022, the Student Senate passed a bill calling for GASP's recognition as an official club, though it has yet to be addressed by administration.[[76]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-:5-78)[[77]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-79)
Athletics
The Pacific Union athletic teams are called the Pioneers. The college is a member of the [National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Association_of_Intercollegiate_Athletics) (NAIA), primarily competing in the [California Pacific Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Pacific_Conference) (CalPac) since the 1996–97 academic year.
Pacific Union competes in eight intercollegiate sports: Men's sports include basketball, cross country, soccer and volleyball; while women's sports include basketball, cross country, soccer and volleyball.
**Accomplishments**
PUC has been awarded the "California Pacific Conference Team Sportsmanship Award" five times since 2003, most recently for the 2010–2011 school year.[[78]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-80) In fall 2011, the coaches for varsity women's volleyball and men's soccer described it as "rebuilding" time.[[79]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-81) This award signifies the school that displays outstanding sportsmanship and exemplifies the true spirit of the "Champions of Character" program set forth by the NAIA.[[80]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-82)[[81]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-83)
**Intramurals**
PUC maintains an active intramural athletic program under the name RecRadio.org.[[82]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-84)[[83]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-85) The intramural athletic program is the top intramural athletics program in the country according to College Prowler's "Best Intramural Sports" ranking.[[84]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Union_College#cite_note-collegeprowlerintramural-86)

Biography:
**Prof. Marsh and the Zodiac Killer**
_By Donn Kraemer and Bill Harris_
_The Oredigger – Colorado School of Mines, Vol. 50, No. 13 (Dec. 15, 1969)_ 

Somewhere in San Francisco an unknown killer possibly plans his next murder, while in Golden a CSM professor works to thwart and expose him.

Professor Donald C. B. Marsh of the Mines math department is currently working on the ciphers sent by the killer, “Zodiac.” In these messages Zodiac tells of his past murders and reportedly gives his name.

Marsh is currently president of the American Cryptogram Association and has been a member for almost twenty years. Since 1960 he has been the editor of the foreign cipher section of the association’s journal.

Will Stevens, a staff writer for the _San Francisco Examiner_, called Dr. Marsh into the Zodiac case last August. Stevens had received Marsh’s name from Farago, author of the book _The Broken Seal_, the story of the cracking of the Japanese codes before World War II.

In briefing Marsh on the killings that had occurred near Vallejo, California, on December 20, 1968, and July 4, 1969, Stevens disclosed that “an individual purporting to be the killer had sent letters accompanied by ciphers to three of the area’s newspapers.” Marsh agreed to help in solving the ciphers, and was able to extract the message from the copies of the code sent to him.

Zodiac apparently enjoys reading news of himself, as he sends to the news media coded messages in which he says lie the clues to his identity and future murders.

And Zodiac said, _“W A → DRF?”_

According to Marsh, some parts of the Zodiac’s messages betray the man as an amateur, while other parts show that the man has some sophisticated knowledge of cryptography. One point of note is the fact that he changes the key, which shows some knowledge of ciphers. However, an educated cryptographer, in drafting a message, would probably use a numerical rather than a symbolic code (such as the one the Zodiac uses), thus giving the ciphers more flexibility in their encoding.

Marsh said, “In my opinion, some errors in the encipherment, as well as in the use of the various symbols rather than simple letters or numbers, indicate that the Zodiac… is not an experienced cryptographer. Each symbol represents a unique letter of the alphabet, but nearly every letter… was assigned more than one symbolic equivalent. These multiple substitutes and the omission of word spaces make the ciphers more difficult than the simple substitution ciphers found in many newspapers and puzzle magazines, but it would not require an expert to devise either of these complications.”

The ciphers consisted of various geometric symbols and alphabet letters, some reversed and inverted, printed in 8” × 17” rectangular arrays. According to Marsh, “the three portions incorporated the same symbols, indicating the likelihood that the same method of encipherment was used in each case.”

The three portions, when deciphered, seemed to make up a single rather wild message, in which the killer did not reveal his name as he had previously promised (“In this cipher is my identity.”).

Marsh also related fears by many people involved that the current Sharon Tate murder case will sting Zodiac’s ego, prompting him to commit more murders.

Anxiously meeting the challenge of decoding the messages, Dr. Marsh is currently working on the latest of Zodiac’s cryptograms. He has issued a challenge to the killer, saying that he can decipher the message despite the Zodiac’s efforts to outwit him. Until that time, though, the killer’s identity and future plans may possibly remain as much of an “unsolved puzzle” as they are now.
